Rata metabolică de bază este determinată de energia consumată de către masa musculară. Persoanele cu rată metabolică de bază mare nu iau ușor în greutate. Puteți menține aportul adecvat și echilibrat de carne, pește, produse din soia și produse lactate pentru a mări masa musculară." Metabolismul dvs. bazal standard este %d Cal; persoanele cu o rată metabolică bazală scăzută sunt mai predispuse să ia în greutate și se simt obosite, încearcă să meargă puțin după masă și să alerge o dată pe săptămână. If you choose to land on your midfeet and heels, wear shoes with better cushioning to reduce the impact of landing." When your knees require more protection, you can try landing on your forefeet more. Try running like this Strike the ground right below you, keep your knees slightly bent, lean your body forward. Run as if you were rotating a hot wheel with your feet. Make smaller steps when you increase running speed. Connect running shoes and make sure you land on your forefeet "Turn on Bluetooth and connect shoes before running. Keep Bluetooth on when running." Landing on forefeet/midfeet Striking the ground with your forefeet requires stronger calf muscles and Achilles tendons; landing on your midfeet or heels strongly affects your knees. Only smart shoes can analyze your landing technique Landing on forefeet "When your knees require more protection, you can try landing on your forefeet more. 1) Strike the ground right below you, keep your knees slightly bent, lean your body forward." 2) Run as if you were rotating a hot wheel with your feet. 3) Make smaller steps when you increase running speed. "Fasten the band as tightly as you feel comfortable. Wearing too tight or too loose will affect the heart rate results. Wear the band slightly above the thinnest part of your wrist." Monitor heart rate "Mi Band Pulse and Mi Band 2 are equipped with a heart rate sensor" VO₂ max Your exercise heart rate zone is calculated as below. Select the appropriate heart rate zone can significantly increase the exercise efficiency. Weight Aerobic Anaerobic Heart rate zone Light Flight ratio Steady pace curve Unsteady pace curve Step frequency Step frequency is the number of steps you make per minute when running. "What's step frequency?" Increase your step frequency Runners usually increase their stride to gain speed. However, using this method can result in muscle damage. You can try to increase your step frequency to gain speed. Long-distance runners usually make 180 steps per minute. We recommend using this value as your step frequency goal. Connect band to make sure your step frequency is detected. "Turn on Bluetooth and connect band before running. Keep Bluetooth on when running." Step frequency goal "Pace is one of the speed definitions generally used in a marathon. It's the time required for you to run 1 km." Keeping consistent speed throughout the run is key. A steady pace curve means you did well. Pace can be measured easier. During a marathon, you can adjust your pace according to the split time of a certain distance. Why not use speed per hour? Landing on forefeet Landing on forefeet/midfeet Pros and cons When running slowly, most people would naturally land on their midfeet or heels. When the running speed increases, more people would strike the ground with their forefeet. For example, most sprinters choose to land on their forefeet when running. Landing on your midfeet or heels strongly affects your knees. Striking the ground with your forefeet requires stronger calf muscles and Achilles tendons. Pace Tempo run "Pace is one of the speed definitions generally used in a marathon. It's the time required for you to run 1 km." "Tempo run needs a good control and plan of your physical strength. Strength distribution is the key to a long-distance running, and it depends on the pace you planned to have. With different speeds used, tempo run can divide into easy run, long run and lactate-threshold run, etc. A consistent and continuous speed is needed and beneficial to exert your strength fully in a marathon." Stride means the distance covered by a step when walking or running. Find the fittest stride of your own "Land on your forefeet. Make sure the landing point is close to your body's gravity center. Press your feet firmly against the ground with every stride." Step frequency goal Long-distance runners usually make 180 steps per minute. We recommend using this value as your step frequency goal. Step frequency is the number of steps you make per minute when running. Increase your step frequency Runners usually increase their stride to gain speed. However, using this method can result in muscle damage. You can try to increase your step frequency to gain speed. Take a smaller stride For most amateur runners, slow step frequency and big stride will make the landing point of the feet fall in front of the center of gravity. Like braking, it will force you move backwards, thus bring poor energy efficiency and higher risks of injury. Ground contact time Ground contact time & injuries "You are more likely to get injured when your feet stay in contact with the ground longer, as your body weight is applied to one of your feet for a more extended period of time. Shorter contact time might lower the risk of injuries." \"Ground contact time\" is the time your feet stay in contact with the ground. It decreases as you go faster. Only smart shoes can analyze your ground contact time Ground contact time (GCT) Reducing ground contact time "Keep your GCT between 160-200 ms. Here's how you can keep it shorter: don't land on your heels, shorten your stride, and strengthen your Achilles tendons. Consult a physician to get exercise recommendations for your Achilles tendons. Keep working on your running technique."
